revision.comment: /* Legacy */ Cited an earlier edition of the children's book Ducky. Consolidated both kids books into one paragraph and added more author info.
revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=September 2018}} {{short description|Plastic bath toys made famous by the work of Curtis Ebbesmeyer, an oceanographer who models ocean currents on the basis of flotsam movements.}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} [[File:Friendly Floatees.png|thumb|360px|Route taken by the Friendly Floatees initially lost in the Pacific Ocean in 1992.]]<!--really nice map but a bit inaccurate; spill occurred much farther north, just south of the Aleutians--> [[File:Curtis Ebbesmeyer-2.JPG|thumb|[[Oceanographer]] [[Curtis Ebbesmeyer]] with [[flotsam]] (including some Friendly Floatees) that he observes to monitor [[ocean currents]].]] '''Friendly Floatees'''{{clarify|Where did "Friendly" come from? original package just says "Floatees"|date=December 2014}} are plastic bath toys marketed by [[The First Years, Inc]]. and made famous by the work of [[Curtis Ebbesmeyer]], an oceanographer who models [[ocean current]]s on the basis of [[flotsam]] movements. Ebbesmeyer studied the movements of a consignment of 29,000 Friendly Floatees—yellow ducks, red beavers, blue turtles and green frogs—which were washed into the Pacific Ocean in 1992. Some of the toys landed along Pacific Ocean shores, such as Hawaii. Others traveled over 17,000 miles, floating over the site where the ''[[RMS Titanic|Titanic]]'' sank, and spent years frozen in Arctic ice to reach the [[East Coast of the United States|Eastern Seaboard]], British and Irish shores 15 years later in 2007.<ref name="Mail-1000s">{{cite news |first=Ben |last=Clerkin |title=Thousands of rubber ducks to land on British shores after 15 year journey|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-464768/Thousands-rubber-ducks-land-British-shores-15-year-journey.html |publisher=[[Daily Mail]] |date=27 June 2007 |accessdate=12 March 2018}}</ref>
==Oceanography== A consignment of Friendly Floatee toys, manufactured in China for The First Years Inc., departed from [[Hong Kong]] on a [[container ship]], the ''Ever Laurel'',<ref>{{cite book |last=Hohn |first=Donovan |date=March 2011 |title=The True Story of 28,800 Bath Toys Lost at Sea and of the Beachcombers, Oceanographers, Environmentalists, and Fools, Including the Author, Who Went in Search of Them |url= |location= |publisher= |isbn= 9780670022199 |accessdate= }} </ref> destined for [[Tacoma, Washington]]. On 10 January 1992, during a storm in the North Pacific Ocean close to the [[International Date Line]], twelve 40-foot (12-m) [[intermodal container]]s were washed overboard. One of these containers held 28,800 Floatees,<ref name="Harper's">{{Cite news | title = Moby-Duck: Or, The Synthetic Wilderness of Childhood | last = Hohn | first = Donovan | date = January 2007 | publisher = [[Harper's Magazine]] | url = http://mysite.verizon.net/donovanhohn/Moby-Duck.html}}</ref> a child's bath toy which came in a number of forms: red [[beaver]]s, green frogs, blue turtles and yellow [[rubber duck|duck]]s. At some point, the container opened (possibly because it collided with other containers or the ship itself) and the Floatees were released. Although each toy was mounted in a plastic housing attached to a backing card, subsequent tests showed that the cardboard quickly degraded in sea water allowing the Floatees to escape. Unlike many bath toys, Friendly Floatees have no holes in them so they do not take on water.
Seattle oceanographers Curtis Ebbesmeyer and James Ingraham, who were working on an ocean surface current model, began to track their progress. The mass release of 28,800 objects into the ocean at one time offered significant advantages over the standard method of releasing 500–1000 drift bottles. The recovery rate of objects from the Pacific Ocean is typically around 2%, so rather than the 10 to 20 recoveries typically seen with a drift bottle release, the two scientists expected numbers closer to 600. They were already tracking various other spills of flotsam, including 61,000 [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] running shoes that had been lost overboard in 1990.
Ten months after the incident, the first Floatees began to wash up along the [[Alaska]]n coast. The first discovery consisted of ten toys found by a [[Beachcombing|beachcomber]] near [[Sitka, Alaska]] on 16 November 1992, about 2,000 miles<!--are these really [[statute mile]]s, and if so, WHY?--> (3,200 km) from their starting point. Ebbesmeyer and Ingraham contacted beachcombers, coastal workers, and local residents to locate hundreds of the beached Floatees over a 530 mile (850 km) shoreline. Another beachcomber discovered twenty of the toys on 28 November 1992, and in total 400 were found along the eastern coast of the [[Gulf of Alaska]] in the period up to August 1993. This represented a 1.4% recovery rate. The landfalls were logged in Ingraham's computer model OSCUR (Ocean Surface Currents Simulation), which uses measurements of air pressure from 1967 onwards to calculate the direction of and speed of wind across the oceans, and the consequent surface currents. Ingraham's model was built to help fisheries but it is also used to predict flotsam movements or the likely locations of those lost at sea.
Using the models they had developed, the oceanographers correctly predicted further landfalls of the toys in [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington state]] in 1996 and theorized that many of the remaining Floatees would have travelled to [[Alaska]], westward to Japan, back to Alaska, and then drifted northwards through the [[Bering Strait]] and become trapped in the [[Arctic]] pack ice. Moving slowly with the ice across the Pole, they predicted it would take five or six years for the toys to reach the North Atlantic where the ice would thaw and release them. Between July and December 2003, The First Years Inc. offered a $100 US [[savings bond]] reward to anybody who recovered a Floatee in [[New England]], Canada or Iceland.<ref name="Mail-1000s"/> More of the toys were recovered in 2004 than in any of the preceding three years. However, still more of these toys were predicted to have headed eastward past Greenland and make landfall on the southwestern shores of the United Kingdom in 2007. In July 2007, a retired teacher found a plastic duck on the Devon coast, and British newspapers mistakenly announced that the Floatees had begun to arrive.<ref>{{Cite news | title = First of the plastic duck invasion fleet makes landfall on the Devon coast | date = 2000-07-14 | publisher = ''[[The Times]]'' | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article2072458.ece | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | title = The First of the Duck Armada | last = Coles | first = John | date = 14 July 2007 | work = [[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]] | url = http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/article246146.ece}}</ref> But the day after breaking the story, the Western Morning News, the local Devon newspaper, reported that Dr. Simon Boxall of the National Oceanography Centre in Southampton had examined the specimen and determined that the duck was not in fact a Floatee.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Expert rules out toy duck as lost ocean adventurer | date = 14 July 2007 | publisher = ''Western Morning News''}}</ref>
Bleached by sun and seawater, the ducks and beavers had faded to white, but the turtles and frogs had kept their original colors.
==Legacy== At least two children's books have been inspired by the Floatees. In 1997, [[Houghton_Mifflin_Harcourt|Clarion Books]] published ''Ducky'' ({{ISBN|0-395-75185-3}}), written by [[Eve Bunting]] and illustrated by [[Caldecott_Medal|Caldecott Medal]] winner [[David Wisniewski]]. [[Hans_Christian_Andersen_Award|Hans Christian Andersen Award]] winner [[Eric Carle]] wrote ''10 Little Rubber Ducks'' (Harper Collins 2005, {{ISBN|978-0-00-720242-3}}).<ref name=ft>{{cite news|last=Wilkinson|first=Carl|title=Ugly Ducklings|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/81ea32a4-5732-11e1-be25-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1n2AiRVJ0|accessdate=21 February 2012|newspaper=Financial Times|date=17 February 2012}}</ref>
In 2011, [[Donovan Hohn]] published ''[[Moby-Duck|Moby-Duck: The True Story of 28,800 Bath Toys Lost at Sea and of the Beachcombers, Oceanographers, Environmentalists, and Fools, Including the Author, Who Went in Search of Them]]'' (Viking, {{ISBN|978-0-670-02219-9}})<ref>{{cite news |title=Moby-Duck: The True Story of 28,800 Bath Toys Lost at Sea by Donovan Hohn|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/mar/30/moby-duck-toys-donovan-hohn |publisher=The Guardian |date=30 March 2012 }}</ref>
On 20 June 2014, [[The Disney Channel]] and [[Disney Junior]] aired ''Lucky Duck'', a Canadian-American animated tv movie that is loosely based on and inspired by the Friendly Floatees.<ref>{{cite web |title=Lucky Duck |url=http://disneyjunior.com/lucky-duck |publisher=[[Disney Junior]] |accessdate=12 March 2018}}</ref>
The toys themselves have become collector's items, fetching prices as high as $1,000.
==See also== * [[Drifter (floating device)]] * [[Great Pacific garbage patch]] * [[Marine debris]] * [[Message in a bottle]]
==Footnotes== {{Reflist}} {{Refbegin}}
==References== *Hohn, Donovan, ''Moby-Duck: The True Story of 28,800 Bath Toys Lost at Sea and of the Beachcombers, Oceanographers, Environmentalists, and Fools, Including the Author, Who Went in Search of Them''. Viking, New York, NY 2011, {{ISBN|978-0-670-02219-9}} *{{cite journal|journal=Earth in Space |volume=7 |issue=2 |date=October 1994 |pages=7–9, 14 |url=http://www.agu.org/sci_soc/ducks.html |title=Pacific Toy Spill Fuels Ocean Current Pathways Research |author=Curtis C. Ebbesmeyer and W. James Ingraham Jr. |accessdate=15 November 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061005100806/http://www.agu.org/sci_soc/ducks.html |archivedate=5 October 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} *{{cite web|url=http://www.thefirstyears.com/duckies.html |title=Ducks embark on a scientific journey|publisher=The First Years Inc.|year=2003|accessdate=15 November 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20031001221100/http://www.thefirstyears.com/duckies.html |archivedate = 1 October 2003}} *{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2003/07/31/eveningnews/main566138.shtml|title=Rubber Duckies Map The World|publisher=CBS News|date=31 July 2003|accessdate=15 November 2006}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.seabean.com/newsletters/vol11-1.pdf|title=The Drifting Seed newsletter|author=Ed Perry, Ed.|date=May 2005|accessdate=15 November 2006|format=PDF}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.beachcombers.org/RubberDuckies.html|title=Beachcombing Science from Bath Toys|author=Curtis C. Ebbesmeyer|date=|accessdate=15 November 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061110180943/http://www.beachcombers.org/RubberDuckies.html|archivedate=10 November 2006|df=dmy-all}} *{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article1996553.ece|title=Plastic duck armada is heading for Britain after 15-year global voyage|author=Simon de Bruxelles|date=28 June 2007|accessdate=28 June 2007 | location=London | work=The Times}} {{Refend}}
==External links== *[http://www.islandnet.com/~see/weather/elements/shoes.htm Keith C. Heidorn, 'Of Shoes And Ships And Rubber Ducks And A Message In A Bottle'], ''The Weather Doctor'' (17 March 1999). *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/3060579.stm Jane Standley, 'Ducks' odyssey nears end'], ''BBC News'', (12 July 2003). *[http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/08/06/1060064238597.html Duck ahoy], ''The Age'', (7 August 2003) *Marsha Walton, [http://cnn.at/2003/TECH/science/05/26/coolsc.oceansecrets/index.html 'How Nikes, toys and hockey gear help ocean science'], CNN.com (26 May 2003). *[http://www.spiegel.de/reise/aktuell/0,1518,491506,00.html "Journey of the Floatees"], Spiegel magazine (1 July 2007) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927161150/http://www.rubaduck.com/news/rubber_duck_news-200302-duckies_around_the_world.htm "Timeline of Rubber Duck Voyage"], Rubaduck.com *Donovan Hohn, [http://www.harpers.org/archive/2007/01/0081345 "Moby-Duck: Or, The Synthetic Wilderness of Childhood,"] ''[[Harper's Magazine]]'', January (2007), pp. 39–62. *[http://www.donovanhohn.com/Home.html Moby Duck: The True Story of 28,800 Bath Toys Lost at Sea and of the Beachcombers, Oceanographers, Environmentalists, and Fools, Including the Author, Who Went in Search of Them] – follow up non-fiction book based on 2 years research after the Harper's Magazine article.

The [[Bayer designation]] κ Ceti ('''Kappa Ceti''') is shared by two [[star]]s in the [[constellation]] of [[Cetus]]:
* {{Bayer|Kappa|1|Ceti}}: a [[yellow dwarf]] [[star]] approximately 29 [[light-year]]s away. * {{Bayer|Kappa|2|Ceti}}: a [[yellow giant]] star ten times as distant.
{{Set index article |astronomical objects}}
[[Category:Bayer objects|Ceti, Kappa]] [[Category:Cetus (constellation)]]

{{Infobox mineral | name = Kassite | category = Hydroxide mineral | boxwidth = | boxbgcolor = | image = | caption = | formula = CaTi2O4(OH)2 | molweight = 235.09 g/mol | strunz = 4.DH.10 | dana = 08.03.09 | system = [[Monoclinic]] | class = Prismatic (2/m)
(same [[H-M symbol]]) | symmetry = ''P2''1/a | color = Brown red, colorless, light yellow | habit = Pseudo hexagonal | lattice = | twinning = : Common, on {101} and {181}. | cleavage = {010} Perfect, {101} Indistinct | fracture = Brittle | tenacity = Very Brittle | mohs = 5 | luster = Adamantine | refractive = nα = 1.95, nβ = 2.13, nγ = 2.21 | opticalprop = Biaxial (–), 2V=58°, Dispersion very strong, r > v | birefringence = δ = 0.26 | pleochroism = none | streak = White | gravity = 3.42 | density = 3.42 | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | diaphaneity = | other = Not radioactive | references = [http://webmineral.com/data/Kassite.shtml Kassite at Webmineral][http://www.mindat.org/min-2166.html Kassite at Mindat]}} '''Kassite''' is a rare mineral whose chemical formula is CaTi2O4(OH)2. It crystallizes in the [[orthorhombic]] [[crystal system]] and forms radiating rosettes and pseudo-hexagonal tabular crystals which are commonly [[Crystal twinning|twinned]]. Kassite crystals are brownish pink to pale yellow in color, are translucent, and have an adamantine luster. Cleavage is distinctly visible, and the crystals are very brittle. It was first described in 1965 in the Afrikanda [[pyroxenite]] [[massif]], a formation on [[Russia]]'s [[Kola Peninsula]] and was named for [[Nikolai Grigorievich Kassin]] (1885–1949), a prominent Russian geologist. It occurs as [[miarolitic|miarolytic]] cavity fillings of alkalic [[pegmatite]]s in the Kola occurrence and in [[nepheline syenite]] in the [[Magnet Cove igneous complex]] of [[Arkansas]], US. Its mineral association includes [[cafetite]] (which with it is also polymorphous), [[perovskite]], [[titanite]], [[rutile]] and [[ilmenite]]. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Oxide minerals]] [[Category:Monoclinic minerals]] {{oxide-mineral-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox Australian place |type= protected | name = Koonadan Historic Site | state = nsw | coordinates = {{coord|34|29|47.8|S|146|21|43.2|E|display=inline,title}} | map_alt = | nearest_town_or_city = [[Leeton, New South Wales|Leeton]] | area = 0.22 | area_footnotes = <ref name="NPWS"/> | established = {{start date|1983|11||df=y}} | established_footnotes = <ref name="Gaz"/> | managing_authorities = [[National Parks and Wildlife Service (New South Wales)|NSW National Parks & Wildlife Service]] | url = https://www.nationalparks.nsw.gov.au/visit-a-park/parks/koonadan-historic-site }} '''Koonadan Historic Site''' is a [[Wiradjuri]] ceremonial and burial grounds, and designated 'Aboriginal Place', located 9km northwest of [[Leeton, New South Wales|Leeton]], [[New South Wales]].<ref name="HA">{{cite web |url=http://environment.nsw.gov.au/heritageapp/ViewHeritageItemDetails.aspx?ID=5062945 |title=Koonadan|work=Office of Environment and Heritage | accessdate = 27 July 2018}}</ref> The site has a picnic shelter with signs that tell the story of the site, with artwork by local Aboriginal people.<ref name="NPWS">{{cite web |url=https://www.nationalparks.nsw.gov.au/visit-a-park/parks/koonadan-historic-site |title=Koonadan Historic Site|work=NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service | accessdate = 27 July 2018}}</ref>
==Overview== Prior to european colonisation of [[Australia]] and the encroachment of settlers into Wiradjuri lands, the Koonadan [[Lunette (geology)|lunette]] dune served as a hunting and fishing ground for Wiradjuri people due to its location next to [[Fivebough and Tuckerbil Wetlands|Tuckerbil Swamp]]. A [[Bora (Australian)|bora]] ground was also located between the Koonadan dune and Tuckerbil Swamp, but evidence of it has been erased by changes in land use.<ref name="pom">{{cite web|work=[[National Parks and Wildlife Service (New South Wales)|NSW National Parks & Wildlife Service]]|date=September 1996|title=Koonadan Historic Site: Plan of management |url=http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/resources/parks/pomFinalKoonadan.pdf|type=PDF|publisher=[[Government of New South Wales]]|accessdate=27 July 2018|isbn=0-7310-0855-3}}</ref><ref name="LALC">{{cite web |url=http://www.ldlalc.com.au/significant-sites/koonadan-aboriginal-place |title=Koonadan Aboriginal Place|work=Leeton & District Local Aboriginal Land Council | accessdate = 27 July 2018}}</ref> In the late [[19th century]], many Wiradjuri were removed from the Koonadan area to [[Warangesda Aboriginal Mission|Warangesda]] and [[Euabalong]], not returning to until the gradual closing of Aboriginal [[Mission (station)|missions]] and reserves between the mid-1920's to 1950's, when many settled in Leeton and [[Narrandera]].<ref name="HA"/>
After the 1950's, the site was cleared of trees, and Tuckerbil Swamp was drained, which has greatly diminished the areas food resources.<ref name="HA"/>
In the early 1980's, sand mining of the Koonadan dune unearthed skeletal remains associated with two different skeletons, which were then reburied by the local Aboriginal community.<ref name="HA"/> The recommencement of sand mining led to protests and blockading of the site by the local Wiradjuri community, leading to the end of sand mining at Koonadan. An agreement between the landholder and NSW government saw the eventual purchase of the southern part of the Koonadan dune, which was then declared an 'Aboriginal place' under the [[National Parks and Wildlife Act 1974|NSW National Parks and Wildlife Act]].<ref name="HA"/><ref name="Gaz">{{cite web|work=Department of Planning and Environment|date=November 1983|title=National Parks and Wildlife Act 1974 |url=http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/resources/cultureheritage/gazette/Koonadan.pdf|type=PDF|publisher=[[Government of New South Wales]]|accessdate=27 July 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Sacred sites]] [[Category:Australian Aboriginal cultural history]]

{{Infobox film | name = La Brèche | image = | caption = | director = Abdoul Aziz Cissé | producer = Diwaan, Gsara, Media Centre Dakar | writer = | starring = | distributor = | released = 2007 | runtime = 35 minutes | country = [[Belgium]]
[[Senegal]] | language = | budget = | gross = | screenplay = Abdoul Aziz Cissé | cinematography = Ousseynou Ndiaye | editing = Philippe Boucq | music = }} '''''La Brèche''''' is a 2007 documentary film. == Synopsis == In [[Saint-Louis, Senegal|Saint-Louis]], a city built in the center of the [[Senegal River]]'s delta, it is common to make an offering to the water genies when a child is born. It is a sign of the importance of water as a symbol to people whose daily lives are marked by [[ritual]]s. Since the 1980s, the infrastructures built to control the delta's volume endanger its [[ecosystem]], while the villages grow more and more desperate in the face of total indifference.{{cite news |last=Barlet |first=Olivier |title="Cinéma(s) d'afrique(s)" 2007: Nouveaux documentaires sénégalais |url=http://www.africultures.com/php/index.php?nav=article&no=7036 |accessdate=12 March 2012 |newspaper=Africulture |date=27 October 2007}} == Awards == * Prix Walter Benjamin * Festival International du Film de Quartier (Dakar, 2007) * Rencontres Cinématographiques de Cerbère (2007) == References == {{RefFCAT|152}} {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Breche, La}} [[Category:2007 films]] [[Category:Belgian films]] [[Category:Senegalese films]] [[Category:Belgian documentary films]] [[Category:Senegalese documentary films]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:Short documentary films]] [[Category:Belgian short films]] [[Category:2000s short films]] [[Category:Documentary films about water and the environment]] [[Category:Environment of Senegal]] [[Category:Water and religion]] [[Category:Senegalese short films]] {{Senegal-film-stub}} {{environment-documentary-film-stub}}

{{about|a creature from Basque mythology|the figure from Greek mythology|Lamia}} {{Multiple issues| {{tone|date=June 2012}} {{refimprove|date=August 2012}} }} [[File:Lamina1.jpg|right|upright=0.6|thumb|[[Basque people|Basque]] lamina]] [[File:Lamia Garagartzan Arrasate 2007-01-01.JPG|right|thumb|Sculpture of a lamina in Garagartza, [[Arrasate]], Gipuzkoa]]
The '''lamia''' (plural: '''lamiak''') is a [[Siren (mythology)|siren]]- or [[nereid]]-like creature in [[Basque mythology]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.euskaltzaindia.net/index.php?option=com_oeh&view=frontpage&Itemid=413&lang=eu |title=lamia |author= |date= |website=Orotariko Euskal Hiztegia |publisher=[[Euskaltzaindia|Euskaltzaindia (Academy of the Basque Language)]] |accessdate=12 July 2012}}</ref><ref name="Williams, 1989">{{Cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PZdinjNiimYC&pg=PA107 | title=Basque Legends in their Social Context | publisher=Basque Studies Program | website=Essays In Basque Social Anthropology And History | year=1989 | accessdate=July 12, 2012 | author=Williams, Elena Arana | pages=119–120| isbn=9781877802027 }}</ref> ''Lamiak'', ''laminak'' or ''amilamiak'' live in the river. They are very beautiful, and stay at the shore combing their long hair with a golden comb; they easily charm men. They have duck feet.
In coastal areas, some believed that there were ''itsaslamiak'' in the sea, who had fish tails—a kind of [[mermaid]].
==Beliefs== Lamiak help those who give them presents by providing them with help at work; if a farmer left them food at the river shore, they would eat it at night and in exchange would finish a field he had left unploughed. In some places, bridges were believed to have been built at night by lamiak: Ebrain ([[Bidarray]], [[Lower Navarre]]), Azalain ([[Andoain]], [[Gipuzkoa]]), Urkulu ([[Leintz-Gatzaga]], [[Gipuzkoa]]), [[Liginaga-Astüe]] ([[Labourd]]).
In some places lamiak had to go away if the bridge they were building at night was left unfinished at cockcrow. People believed that lamiak had left a river if a stone of the bridge was missing. Most lamiak disappeared when men built small churches in the forest.
A lamia is at the other side of the rainbow combing her hair. When the sun lights her hair, the rainbow opens.
In some places male lamiak also exist; they are strong and have built [[dolmen]]s at night. Sometimes they can enter a house when its inhabitants are sleeping. They are given different names: ''Maideak'', ''Mairiak'', ''[[Mairuak]]'', ''Intxixuak'' (in [[Oiartzun]], ([[Gipuzkoa]]), ''Saindi Maidi'' (in [[Lower Navarre]]).
Many toponyms are related to lamiak: Lamikiz ([[Markina-Xemein|Markina]]), Laminaputzu (in [[Zeanuri]]), Lamitegi (in [[Bedaio]]), Lamirain (in [[Arano]]), Lamusin (in [[Sare]]), Lamiñosin (in [[Ataun]]).
==See also== *[[Basajaun]] *[[Sorginak]] *[[Mari (goddess)|Mari]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Basque mythology]] [[Category:Female legendary creatures]] [[Category:Human-headed mythical creatures]] [[Category:Mythological human hybrids]] [[Category:Water spirits]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Utricularia'' species}} There are around '''233 species in the genus ''[[Utricularia]]''''', belonging to the Bladderwort family ([[Lentibulariaceae]]). It is the largest genus of [[carnivorous plants]] and has a worldwide distribution, being absent only from Antarctica and the oceanic islands. This genus was considered to have 250 species until Peter Taylor reduced the number to 214 in his exhaustive study, ''[[The genus Utricularia - a taxonomic monograph]]'', published by [[Office of Public Sector Information|HMSO]] (1989). Taylor's classification is generally accepted, though his division of the genus in two subgenera was soon seen as obsolete. Molecular genetic studies have mostly confirmed Taylor's sections with some modifications (Jobson et al., 2003), but reinstalled the division of the genus in three subgenera. This list follows the subgeneric classification ''sensu'' Müller & Borsch (2005), updated with new information in Müller et al. (2006).
For a list of known ''Utricularia'' species by common name, see [[:Category:Utricularia species by common name|''Utricularia'' species by common name]].
{{TOClimit|limit=2}}

page.title: List of durian diseases and pests

revision.comment: Alter: isbn, title. Add: citeseerx, chapter-url. Removed accessdate with no specified URL. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[User:NessieVL|NessieVL]]
revision.text:
[[File:07302jfBlack ants eating Durians in the Philippinesfvf 20.jpg|thumb|right|[[Black garden ant]]s (''Lasius niger'') eating a durian at a market in [[Pulilan, Bulacan]]. Notice the spot of mold as well.]] Durian is an agricultural product affected my many [[plant pathology|plant pathogens]] and [[Pest (organism)|pests]]. Most of the information here concerns ''[[Durio zibethinus]]'', the major commercial species, but a [[List of Durio species|dozen species]] in the ''[[Durio]]'' genus are edible durians, and several of those are also grown commercially and these diseases can concern them as well.
==Algae== *algal leaf spot, red rust (''[[Cephaleuros virescens]]'')<ref name="Brown" /><ref name="Lim">{{cite book |last1=Lim |first1=Tong Kwee |last2=Sangchote |first2=Somsiri |editor1-last=Ploetz |editor1-first=Randy C. |title=Diseases of tropical fruit crops |date=2003 |publisher=CABI Publishing |location=Cambridge, MA |isbn=978-0851993904 |pages=241–252 |chapter-url=https://www.cabi.org/cabebooks/ebook/20033099834 |accessdate=27 June 2018 |language=English |format=PDF |chapter=10: Diseases of durian |doi=10.1079/9780851993904.0241 |oclc=928700703}}</ref><ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Singh1980">{{cite journal |last1=Singh |first1=Kishan Gorbak |title=A check list of host and disease in Malaysia |journal=Bulletin |date=1980 |issue=154 |oclc=9111337}}</ref><ref name="Lim90">{{cite book |last1=Lim |first1=Tong Kwee |title=Durian: diseases and disorders. |date=1990 |publisher=Tropical Press |location=Kuala Lumpur |isbn=9789677300507 |language=English |oclc=857198658}}</ref>
==Animals== ===Vertebrates=== These are animals that eat or destroy durian fruit or trees. Many of these are shot or poisoned by farmers.<ref name="Gasik">{{cite web |last1=Gasik |first1=Lindsay |title=When Durian Isn't Vegan, and What Every Animal Loving Durian Freak Should Know |url=https://www.yearofthedurian.com/2014/03/when-durian-isnt-vegan.html |website=Year of the Durian |publisher=yearofthedurian.com |accessdate=27 June 2018 |language=English |format=HTML |date=8 March 2014}}</ref> Some of these species naturally act as [[seed dispersers]],<ref name="Nakashima" /> which benefits the plant but does not benefit farmers.
*[[black hornbill]] (''Anthracoceros malayanus'')<ref name="Nakashima" /> *squirrel<ref name="Gasik"/> **[[grey-bellied squirrel]] (''Callosciurus caniceps'')<ref name="Brown"/> **[[black-striped squirrel]] (''Callosciurus nigrovittatus'')<ref name="Brown"/> **[[plantain squirrel]] (''Callosciurus notatus'')<ref name="Brown"/> **[[Prevost's squirrel]] (''Callosciurus prevostii'')<ref name="Nakashima">{{cite journal|last1=Nakashima|first1=Yoshihiro|last2=Lagan|first2=Peter|last3=Kitayama|first3=Kanehiro|title=A Study of Fruit–Frugivore Interactions in Two Species of Durian (''Durio'', Bombacaceae) in Sabah, Malaysia|journal=Biotropica|date=March 2008|volume=40|issue=2|pages=255–258|doi=10.1111/j.1744-7429.2007.00335.x|language=English|issn=1744-7429|oclc=5155811169}}</ref> *[[Asian elephant]] (''Elephas maximus'')<ref name="Gasik"/><ref name="Webber">{{cite journal |last1=Webber |first1=C. Elizabeth |last2=Sereivathana |first2=Tuy |last3=Maltby |first3=Matthew P. |last4=Lee |first4=Phyllis C. |title=Elephant crop-raiding and human–elephant conflict in Cambodia: crop selection and seasonal timings of raids |journal=Oryx |date=2011 |volume=45 |issue=2 |pages=243–251 |doi=10.1017/S0030605310000335 |language=English |issn=0030-6053 |oclc=729973313|citeseerx=10.1.1.859.8742 }}</ref> *[[Sun bear]]s (''Helarctos malayanus'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Fredriksson">{{cite journal|last1=Fredriksson|first1=Gabriella M.|last2=Wich|first2=Serge A.|last3=Trisno|title=Frugivory in sun bears (''Helarctos malayanus'') is linked to El Niño-related fluctuations in fruiting phenology, East Kalimantan, Indonesia|journal=Biological Journal of the Linnean Society|date=1 November 2006|volume=89|issue=3|pages=489–508|doi=10.1111/j.1095-8312.2006.00688.x|language=English|issn=1095-8312|quote=''Durio graveolens'' Bombacaceae S fr Tree}}</ref><ref name="Oei-Dharma"/> *[[crab-eating macaque]] (''Macaca fascicularis'')<ref name="Nakashima" /> *[[Rat]]s<ref name="Oei-Dharma">{{cite book |last1=Oei-Dharma |first1=H.P. |title=Use of Pesticides and Control of Economic Pests and Diseases in Indonesia |date=1969 |publisher=E. J. Brill |location=Leiden |page=78 |language=English |oclc=911794968 |chapter=6 Fruit Crops |quote=We think it worth mentioning here, owing to reports of great damage, caused by certain mammals, like rats, wild boars and bears.}}</ref> **[[Malayan field rat]] (''Rattus tiomanicus'')<ref name="Brown"/> *[[Bornean orangutan]] (''Pongo pygmaeus''),<ref name="Mackinnon">{{cite journal|last1=Mackinnon|first1=John|title=The behaviour and ecology of wild orang-utans (''Pongo pygmaeus'')|journal=Animal Behaviour|date=February 1974|volume=22|issue=1|pages=3–74|doi=10.1016/S0003-3472(74)80054-0|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003347274800540|accessdate=22 November 2017|language=English|format=PDF|issn=0003-3472}}</ref> *[[feral pig]] (''Sus scrofa domesticus'') and [[wild boar]] (''Sus scrofa'')<ref name="Gasik"/><ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Oei-Dharma"/> *viverrids ([[Viverridae]] sp.)<ref name="Nakashima" />
===Invertebrates=== Most of these are [[arthropod]]s, but a [[nematode]]s and [[Gastropoda|gastropods]] are also of concern.<ref name="AQIS">{{cite web |author1=Plant Quarantine Policy Branch, Policy and International Division |title=Final Import Risk Analysis on the Importation of Fresh Durian Fruit (''Durio zibethinus'' Murray) from the Kingdom of Thailand |url=http://www.agriculture.gov.au/sitecollectiondocuments/ba/plant/ungroupeddocs/durianfira.doc |publisher=Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service |accessdate=29 June 2018 |location=Canberra |language=English |format=DOC |date=November 1999}}</ref>
====Arthropods==== *''[[Acrocercops]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Adoretus]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Allocaridara malayensis]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *durian psyllid (''[[Allocarsidara malayensis]]'' Syn. ''[[Tenaphalara malayensis]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *leaf roller (''[[Adoxophyes privatana]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *durian leaf hopper (''[[Amrasca durianae]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *shining leaf chafer (''[[Anomala]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> *cotton aphid (''[[Aphis gossypii]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *''[[Apogonia]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf eating beetle (''[[Aprosterna pallida]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *leaf roller (''[[Archips machlopis]]'' syn. ''Cacoecia machlopis'')<ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *leaf eating (''[[Arctornis cygna]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *leaf eating (''[[Arthisma scissuralis]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *coconut scale (''[[Aspidiotus destructor]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *leaf scale (''[[Asterolecanium]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> **''[[Asterolecaniam ungulata]]''<ref name="Brown"/> (probably ''[[Asterolecanium ungulatum]]'') *flower webber ''[[Autoba versicolor]]'' (Syn. ''Eublemma versicolora'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *stem borer (''[[Batocera gultata]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *borer (''[[Canopia]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> *sap beetle (''[[Carpophilus]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> **sap beetle (''[[Carpophilus floveicollis]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Cephonodes ?higlas]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *[[longhorn beetle]] larvae<ref name="Brown"/> (Cerambycidae) *''[[Chalcoscelis albiguttata]]'' -pest of leaves<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf eating, gelatine grub (''[[Chalcocelis albiguttatus]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *[[scale insect]] (Coccoidea)<ref name="Brown"/> *scale insect, soft scale (''[[Coccus (insect)|Coccus]]'' sp.)<ref name="AQIS"/> *durian fruit borer, durian husk borer, yellow peach moth, Queensland bollworm (''[[Conogethes punctiferalis]]'' syn. ''Monogatus puntiferalis'' and ''Dichocrocis punctiferalis'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="AQIS"/> *trunk borer (''[[Conopia]]'' sp.), secondary infection after ''[[Phytophthora palmivora]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf eating bagworm (''[[Cremastopsyche pendulla]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *litchi fruit moth, macadamia nut borer (''[[Cryptophlebia ombrodelta]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *Indo-Malaysian drywood termite (''[[Cryptotermes cynocephalus]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf mining grub (''[[Dactylispa leonardi]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *hawkmoth (''[[Daphnusa ocellaris]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *leaf eating tussock moth (''[[Dasychira inclusa]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *tussock moth (''[[Dasychira mendosa]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *tussock moth (''[[Dasychira osseata]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *''[[Drosophila punctpennis]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf eating caterpillar (''[[Erizada lichenaria]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *African red mite, citrus brown mite (''[[Eutetranychus africanus]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *oriental red mite (''[[Eutetranychus orientalis]]'' Klein misidentification)<ref name="AQIS"/> *cotton leaf roller (''[[Haritalodes derogata]]'' (syn. ''Sylepta derogata'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="AQIS"/> *cotton boll worm (''[[Helicoverpa armigera]]'' formerly ''Heliothis armigera'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *horned treehopper (''[[Hemicentrus attenuatus]]'' (''[[Sarritor attenuatus]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *leaf roller moth (''[[Homona coffearia]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *leaf roller moth (''[[Homono difficilis]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *leaf roller moth (''[[Homona eductana]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *flower eating moth (''[[Horaga onyx onyx]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *leaf eating weevil (''[[Hypomeces squamosus]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *durian fruit borer (''[[Hypoperigea leprosticta]]'' syn. ''[[Plagideicta leprosticta]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *Stem scale insect (''[[Icerya]]'' sp.)<ref name="AQIS"/> *''[[Idiophantis chiridota]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *[[termite]] (Isoptera), specifically lumber of ''[[Durio carinatus]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Lacifer javanus]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *powderpost beetle (''[[Lyctus (beetle)|Lyctus]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf eating caterpillar (''[[Lymantria marginata]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *coconut case worm (''[[Mahasena corbetti]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *thrip (''[[Megalurothrips]]'' sp.)<ref name="AQIS"/> *''[[Microtermes pallidus]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *hairy powderpost beetle (''[[Minthea rugicollis]]''), recorded on ''[[Durio lowianus]]'' and ''[[Durio oxleyanus]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Monolepta bifasciata]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *durian seed borer (''[[Mudaria luteileprosa]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *durian seed borer (''[[Mudaria magniplaga]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Nodostoma]]'' sp.<ref name="AQIS"/> *mite (''[[Oligonychus biharensis]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Orthaga semialba]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *cocoa tussock moth (''[[Orgyia postica]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *tussock moth (''[[Orygia turbata]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *longan leaf-eating looper (''[[Oxyodes scrobiculata]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *leaf eating caterpillar (''[[Paracrama dulcissima]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *''[[Paralecanium expansum]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Paralecanium vacuum]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Phenacaspis hedyoticlis]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Phostria nicoalis]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Phostria xipharesalis]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *durian seed and fruit borer (''[[Plagideicta magniplaga]]'' (syn. ''[[Mudaria magniplaga]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *coffee mealybug (''[[Planococcus lilacinus]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *mealybug (''[[Planococcus minor]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *[[ambrosia beetle]]<ref name="Brown"/> ([[Platypodinae]] or [[Scolytinae]]) *''[[Platypus cupulatus]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *weevil (''[[Platytrachelus psittacinus]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *red coffee borer, red branch borer (''[[Polyphagozerra coffeae]]'' syn. ''Zeuzera coffeae'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="AQIS"/> *up-country tea termite (''[[Postelectrotermes militaris]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *mealybug (''[[Pseudococcus]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> description matches ''[[Planococcus minor]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *flower eating moth (''[[Rapala dieneces dieneces]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *fruit eating moth (''[[Remelana jangala ravata]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *''[[Rhadinomerus]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/> *stem borer (''[[Rhytidodera simulans]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *scale insect, soft scale insect (''[[Saissetia]]'' sp.)<ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Scheloribates]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/> *chilli thrips (''[[Scirtothrips dorsalis]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *''[[Seira jacobsoni]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf eating caterpillar (''[[Setora fletcheri]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *leaf eating (''[[Spilosoma]]'' sp.)<ref name="AQIS"/> *bark feeder (''[[Squamura]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> **''[[Squamura maculata]]'' (syn. ''Indarbela flavina'')<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf eating (''[[Suana concolor]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *''[[Sylepta bipunctalis]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Synanthedon]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Tenaphalara malayensis]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *mite (''[[Tetranychus fijiensis]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/>'<ref name="Brown"/> *thrips (''[[Thrips coloratus]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *thrips (''[[Thrips hawaiiensis]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *oil palm bunch moth (''[[Tirathaba mundella]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *fruit boring caterpillar (''[[Tirathaba ruptilinea]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *leaf eating caterpillar (''[[Tiruvaca subcostalis]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *durian rind borer, fruit borer (''[[Tonica terasella]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *citrus aphid (''[[Toxoptera aurantii]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *mould mite (''[[Tyrophagus putrescentiae]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Xyleborus cordatus]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Xyleborus declivigranulatus]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *typical bark beetle (''[[Xyleborus ferrugineus]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *tea shot hole borer (''[[Xyleborus fornicatus]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/> *''[[Xyleborus formicatus]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Xyleborus similis]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Xyleborus testsceus]]'' (syn. ''[[Xyleborus perforans]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *borer (''[[Zeuzera]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/>
====Other invertebrates==== *spiral nematode ''[[Helicotylenchus]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/> *giant African snail (''[[Lissachatina fulica]]'' formerly ''Achatina fulica'')<ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Macroposthonia]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/> *[[root-knot nematode]] ''Meloidogyne'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/> *lesion nematode ''[[Pratylenchus]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/> **hypocotyl rot (''[[Pratylenchus coffeae]]'')<ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Radopholus]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/> *reniform nematode ''[[Rotylenchulus reniformis]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *stunt nematode ''[[Tylenchorhynchus]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/> *dagger nematode ''[[Xiphinema]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/>
==Bacteria== *stem canker (''[[Enterobacter]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown">{{cite book |last1=Brown |first1=Michael J. |title=Durio, a Bibliographic Review |date=1997 |publisher=Bioversity International |location=New Delhi |isbn=9789290433187 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=3AcGwT0CdSwC&lpg=PA107&dq=Monogatus%20fruit%20borer&pg=PA100#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=1 July 2018 |language=English |format=PNG |oclc=38754437}}</ref> *postharvest fruit rot (''[[Erwinia]]'' sp.)<ref name="Lim"/> <ref name="Lim90"/> <ref name="Sangchote96"/> *stem canker (''[[Flavobacterium]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> *stem canker (''[[Pseudomonas]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/>
==Fungi== [[Fungus|Fungi]] affect both the tree before harvest and the fruit after harvest. Some listed species may only cause cosmetic damage, or the association is unknown.
*stem rot (''[[Albonectria rigidiuscula]]'' syn. ''Calonectria rigidiuscula'', ''Fusarium decemcellulare'')<ref name="Brown"/> *''Sclerotium'' fruit rot (''[[Athelia rolfsii]]'' syn. ''Sclerotium rolfsii'', ''Corticium rolfsii'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/> *leaf fungus (''[[Aschersonia]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *secondary/opportunistic fruit rot (''[[Aspergillus niger]]'' and other ''[[Aspergillus]]'' spp.)<ref name="Sivapalan" /> *stem rot (''[[Bionectria ochroleuca]]'' syn. ''Nectria ochroleuca'')<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Calonectria kyotensis]]''<ref name="Sivapalan">{{cite journal|last1=Sivapalan|first1=A.|last2=Metussin|first2=Rosidah|last3=Harndan|first3=Fuziah|last4=Zain|first4=Rokiah Mohd|title=Fungi associated with postharvest fruit rots of ''Durio graveolens'' and ''D. kutejensis'' in Brunei Darussalam|journal=Australasian Plant Pathology|date=December 1998|volume=27|issue=4|pages=274–277|doi=10.1071/AP98033|language=English|issn=1448-6032|oclc=204773204}}</ref> *secondary/opportunistic fruit rot (''[[Candida (fungus)|Candida]]'' sp.)<ref name="Sivapalan" /> *[[sooty mold]] (''[[Capnodium moniliforme]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf spot (''[[Cercospora]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="AQIS"/> *seedling dieback (''[[Chaetomium trilaterale]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf [[anthracnose]], root rot (''[[Colletotrichum]]'' sp., syn. ''Glomerella'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="AQIS"/> **''[[Colletotrichum durionis]]''<ref name="Brown"/> **''[[Colletotrichum zibethinum]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Coriolus vesicolor]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf spot and dieback (''[[Corticium solani]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf blotch (''[[Corynespora cassiicola]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Curvularia]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf spot (''[[Curvularia affinis]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *scion dieback (''[[Diplodia]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> **die back (''[[Diplodia durionis]]'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="AQIS"/> *root disease (''[[Fusarium]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> **''Fusarium'' fruit rot, stem rot (''[[Fusarium solani]]'' syn. ''Nectria haematococca'', ''Haematonectria haematococca'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Lim90"/><ref name="Sangchote96"/> **''[[Fusarium oxysporum]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *twig blight (''[[Fusicoccum]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="AQIS"/> *''[[Ganoderma pseudoferreus]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Geotrichum candidum]]''<ref name="Sivapalan"/> *secondary/opportunistic fruit rot (''[[Gibberella intricans]]'')<ref name="Sivapalan" /> *''[[Gliocephalotrichum bulbilium]]''<ref name="Sivapalan"/> *leaf spot (''[[Gloeosporium]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> **anthracnose (''[[Gloeosporimn zibethinum]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf anthracnose and leaf spot (''[[Glomerella cingulata]]'' syn. ''Colletotrichum gloeosporioides'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Lim90"/><ref name="Sangchote96">{{cite journal |last1=Sangchote |first1=Somsiri |last2=Pongpisutta |first2=Ratiya |last3=Bunjoedchoedchu |first3=Ronnapop |title=Diseases of durian fruits after harvest |pages=148–152 |journal=34. Kasetsart University Annual Conference, Bangkok (Thailand), 30 Jan-1 Feb 1996 |date=1996}}</ref>?<ref name="Lim80">Lim, Tong Kwee (1980) Anthracnose and related problems in some local fruit trees. National Fruit Seminar, Serdang, Malaysia, November 5–7, 1980, Preprint No. 15.</ref><ref name="Lim90"/><ref name="Sivapalan"/> *black and brown leaf spot (''[[Homostegia durionis]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Lasiodiplodia]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/> *''Diplodia'' fruit rot (''[[Lasiodiplodia theobromae]]'' syn. ''Botryodiplodia theobromae'') - can also cause dieback and [[leaf scorch]]<ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Lim90"/><ref name="Sangchote96"/><ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Sivapalan"/> *''[[Lentinus subnudus]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *sooty mold (''[[Leptoxyphium]]'' sp.)<ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Lim89">Lim, Tong Kwee (1989) Studies of some lesser known mycoflora of durian: sooty mould and black mildew. Pertanika 12, 159–166.</ref><ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Macrophomina phaseolina]]'' (syn. ''Macrophomina phaseoli'')<ref name="Brown"/> *thread blight (''[[Marasmiellus scandens]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *[[black mildew]], sooty mould (''[[Meliola durionis]]'')<ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Turner71">Turner, G.J. (1971) Fungi and plant disease in Sarawak. Phytopathological Paper No. 12, Commonwealth Mycological Institute, Kew, UK.</ref> <ref name="Johnston60">Johnston, A. (1960) A supplement to a host list of plant disease in Malaya. Mycological Paper No. 77. Commonwealth Mycological Institute, Kew, UK</ref><ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Metacapnodium dennisii]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *sooty mold (''[[Metacapnodium moniliforme]]'')<ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Turner71"/><ref name="Johnston60"/> *''Mucor'' rot, fruit rot (''[[Mucor]]'' sp.)<ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Lim90"/><ref name="Sangchote96"/><ref name="Brown"/> *1eaf spot (''[[Myrothecium verrucaria]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *bark rot (''[[Nectria]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> *powdery mildew (''[[Oidium (genus)|Oidium]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> **powdery mildew (''[[Oidium nephelii]]'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="AQIS"/> *leaf mould ''[[Passalora fulva]]'' (syn. ''Cladosporium fulvum''<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="AQIS"/> *secondary/opportunistic fruit rot (''[[Penicillium]]'' sp.)<ref name="Sivapalan" /> *seedling dieback (''[[Perisporium]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf spot (''[[Pestalotia]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="AQIS"/> *pink disease/{{lang|ms|cendawan angin}} (''[[Phanerochaete salmonicolor]]'' syn. ''Botryobasidium salmonicolor'', ''Corticium salmonicolor'', ''Erythricium salmonicolor'')<ref name="Lim"/><ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> *leaf spot (''[[Phomopsis]]'' sp.)<ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/> **''[[Phomopsis]]'' leaf spot, ''Phomopsis'' fruit rot, branch and stem necrosis, leaf spot of seedlings (''[[Phomopsis durionis]]'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Lim90"/><ref name="Sangchote96"/> *sooty mould of fruits, twigs, and leaves (''[[Phragmocapnias betle]]'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Lim89"/> *''[[Phyllachora makrospora]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *seedling rim blight, leaf spot, postharvest fruit rot (''[[Phyllosticta]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Lim90"/><ref name="Sangchote96"/> **rim blight, leaf spot (''[[Phyllosticta durionis]]'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="AQIS"/> *leaf parasite (''[[Placosphaeria durionis]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Plokamidomyces colensoi]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *black crust of fruit, leaf mould, sooty mold (''[[Polychaeton]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Lim89"/> *postharvest fruit rot (''[[Pseudocochliobolus eragrostidis]]'', syn. ''Curvularia eragrostidis'', ''Cochliobolus eragrostidis'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Lim90"/> <ref name="Sangchote96"/> *leaf spot (''[[Pyrenochaeta]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf blight, leaf fall (''[[Rhizoctonia]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> **''Rhizoctonia'' leaf blight, leaf fall, foliar blight, leaf rot (''[[Rhizoctonia solani]]'' syn. ''Thanatephorus cucumeris'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Lim87">Lim, Tong Kwee, Ng, C.C. and Chin, C.L. (1987) Etiology and control of durian foliar blight caused by ''Rhizoctonia solani''. Annals of Applied Biology 110, 301–307.</ref> <ref name="Lim90"/><ref name="AQIS"/> *''[[Rhizopus]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/> **''Rhizopus'' rot, fruit rot (''[[Rhizopus stolonifer]]'' sy. ''Rhizopus artocarpi'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/> <ref name="Lim90"/><ref name="Sangchote96"/> *wood rot, white root disease (''[[Rigidoporus microporus]]'' syn.''Fomes lignosus'', ''Rigidoporus lignosus'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/> *''[[Typhula]]'' sp. (syn. ''[[Sclerotium]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> *sooty mold (''[[Scorias spongiosa]]'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Lim89"/> *leaf mould (''[[Spiropes capensis]]'' syn. ''[[Helminthosporium capensis]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Trametes persoonii]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *sooty mould of twigs, petioles, and leaves (''[[Trichomerium grandisporum]]'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Lim89"/> *black film on leaves, sooty mold (''[[Trichopeltheca asiatica]]'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Lim89"/> *sooty mold ''[[Tripospermum]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Lim89"/> *scion dieback (''[[Ustulina]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Verticillium]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown"/>
==Oomycetes== [[Oomycete]]s are often confused with fungi.
*''[[Phytophthora botryosa]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *leaf blight (''[[Phytophthora nicotianae var. nicotianae]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Phytophthora nicotianae var. parasitica]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *bark rot, fruit rot, hypocotyl rot, patch canker, root rot (''[[Phytophthora palmivora]]'')<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/><ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Lim90"/><ref name="Sangchote96"/><ref name="ChanLim87">Chan, L.G. and Lim, Tong Kwee (1987) Control of ''Phytophthora palmivora'' on cacao and durian seedlings. Journal of Plant Protection in the Tropics 4(1), 9–13.</ref><ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Phytophthora parasitica]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *root rot (''[[Pythium]]'' sp.)<ref name="Brown"/> **''Pythium'' root rot, patch canker, root disease (''[[Pythium vexans]]'' syn. ''Pythium complectans'', ''Phytopythium vexans''<ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Lim"/>
==Plants== Some [[plant]]s growing on durian trees can be problematic or even [[parasitism|parasitic]]. *dragon scales (''[[Drymoglossum piloselloides]]'')<ref name="Brown" /> *[[mistletoe]] (''[[Elytranthe barnesii]]'')<ref name="Brown" /> *mistletoe (''[[Loranthus pentandrus]]'')<ref name="Brown" />
==Non-pathogenic epiphytes and symbiotes== These species live on or in durian trees as [[epiphyte]]s but typically do not harm the tree or fruit. However, ''[[Trentepohlia (alga)|Trentepohlia]]'' species can grow thick enough to block [[lenticel]]s and inhibit [[Ramiflory|ramiflorous]] flowering.<ref name="Lim"/>
*''[[Aschersonia placentae]]'' (teleomorph: ''[[Hypocrella raciborskii]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Diploicia canescens]]'' (formerly ''Buellia canescens''<ref name="Brown" /> *oakleaf fern (''[[Drynaria quercifolia]]'') Anderson (1966)<ref name="Brown" /> *[[strangler fig|strangling fig]] (''[[Ficus benjamina]]'') Anderson (1966)<ref name="Brown" /> *''[[Hypocrella raciborskii]]'' (syn. ''[[Aschersonia placentae]]'')<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Parmelia (fungus)|Parmelia]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown" /> *''[[Phycopeltis]]''<ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Brown" /> *''[[Pleurococcus]]''<ref name="Lim"/> **''[[Pleurococcus nagelii]]''<ref name="Brown" /> *''[[Trebouxia]]''<ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Brown" /> *''[[Trentepohlia (alga)|Trentepohlia]]'' sp.<ref name="Brown" /> **''[[Trentepohlia arboreum]]''<ref name="Lim"/><ref name="LK89b">{{cite journal |last1=Lim |first1=Tong Kwee |last2=Sijam |first2=Kamaruzaman |title=Occurrence of the green alga ''Trentepohlia'' on the trunk and branches of durian |journal=The Planter |date=1989 |volume=65 |pages=328–333 |url=http://psasir.upm.edu.my/id/eprint/38721/ |oclc=956938423 |issn=0126-575X}}</ref> **''[[Trentepohlia arborum]]'' (syn. ''[[Trentepohlia bisporangiata]]'')<ref name="Brown" /> **''[[Trentepohlia aurea]]''<ref name="Lim"/><ref name="LK89b"/><ref name="Brown" /> **''[[Trentepohlia monile]]'' (syn. ''[[Physolinum monilis]]'', ''[[Trentepohlia moniliformis]]'')<ref name="Brown" /><ref name="Lim"/><ref name="LK89b"/> *[[Velvet felt]], felt fungus (''[[Septobasidium]]'' sp.)<ref name="Lim"/><ref name="Lim90"/><ref name="Chandrasikul62">Chandrasikul, A. (1962) A Preliminary Host List of Plant Disease in Thailand. Technical Bulletin No. 6, Department of Agriculture, Bangkok, Thailand.</ref><ref name="AQIS"/><ref name="Brown"/>
==Hyperparasites and secondary associations== [[Hyperparasite|Hyperparasitism]] is when durian [[Parasitism|parasites]] become the hosts for other parasites.
*''[[Aschersonia placenta]]'' is a pest of ''[[Asterolecanium ungulata]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Bionectria ochroleuca]]'' (syn. ''Nectria ochroleuca'') is associated with ''[[Albonectria rigidiuscula]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Gliocladium roseum]]'' is a parasite of ''[[Phytophthora palmivora]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Hypocrella raciborskii]]'' is a pest of ''[[Asterolecanium ungulata]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Loranthus ferrugineus]]'' can parasitize ''[[Viscum articulatum]]'', which can be a parasite of ''[[Elytranthe barnesii]]''<ref name="Brown"/> *''[[Nectria haemalococca]]'' is associated with ''[[Albonectria rigidiuscula]]''<ref name="Brown"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}

page.title: List of gravitationally rounded objects of the Solar System

revision.comment: Undid revision 865010800 by [[Special:Contributions/General Ization|General Ization]] ([[User talk:General Ization|talk]]) The IP's earlier edits seemed to be constructive.
revision.text:
{{Lists of Solar System objects}} This is a '''list of gravitationally rounded objects of the Solar System''', which are objects that have a rounded, [[ellipsoid]]al shape due to the forces of their own gravity ([[hydrostatic equilibrium]]). Their sizes range from [[dwarf planet]]s and moons to the [[planet]]s and the [[Sun]]. This list does not include any [[small Solar System body|small Solar System bodies]], but it does include a sample of planetary-mass objects whose shape has yet to be accurately determined. The Sun's orbital characteristics are listed in relation to the [[Galactic Center]], while all other objects are listed in order of their distance from the Sun. == Sun == {{Main article|Sun}} The [[Sun]] is a [[G-type main-sequence star]]. It contains almost 99.9 percent of all the mass in the [[Solar System]].{{cite journal |first=Michael Mark |last=Woolfson |author-link=Michael Woolfson |title=The Origin and Evolution of the Solar System |doi=10.1046/j.1468-4004.2000.00012.x |date=2000 |journal=Astronomy & Geophysics |volume=41 |issue=1 |pages=1.12 |bibcode=2000A&G....41a..12W }} {| class="wikitable" border="1" style="text-align: center;" |- ! colspan="2" style="background: #fffdd0;" | ! style="background: yellow;" | [[Sun]][http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Sun&Display=Facts&System=Metric NASA Solar System exploration Sun factsheet] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080102034758/http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Sun&Display=Facts&System=Metric |date=2008-01-02 }} and [http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/sunfact.html NASA Sun factsheet] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100715200549/http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/sunfact.html |date=2010-07-15 }} ''NASA'' Retrieved on 2008-11-17 (unless otherwise cited) |- | colspan="2" style="background: #fffdd0;" | | style="background: yellow;" | [[File:Sun in February.jpg|70x70px]] |- | colspan="2" style="background: #fffdd0;" | [[Astronomical symbol|Astronomical symbol]]{{ref label|Q|q|none}} | style="background: yellow;" | [[File:Sun symbol.svg|20px]] |- | style="background: #fffdd0;" | Mean distance

[[Hydrogen|H]], [[Helium|He]], [[Oxygen|O]], [[Carbon|C]], [[Iron|Fe]], [[sulfur|S]] |} == Planets == {{Main article|Planet}} {| class="wikitable floatright" style="text-align: left; background-color: #eaeaea;" |- ! colspan=3 | Key |- | style="background-color: #eeffee; vertical-align: top;" width=55 | *
[[Terrestrial planet]] | style="background-color: #fffaee; vertical-align: top;" width=55 | °
[[Gas giant]] | style="background-color: #ffe6ea; vertical-align: top;" width=55 | †
[[Ice giant]] |} A [[planet]] is defined according to the 2006 [[International Astronomical Union]] (IAU) definition as a body in orbit around the [[Sun]] that was large enough to have achieved [[hydrostatic equilibrium]] and to have [[Clearing the neighbourhood|cleared the neighbourhood around its orbit]].{{cite press release |date=2006-08-24 |publisher=International Astronomical Union (News Release – IAU0603) |title=IAU 2006 General Assembly: Result of the IAU Resolution votes |url=http://www.iau.org/news/pressreleases/detail/iau0603/ |accessdate=2007-12-31 }} ([http://www.iau.org/iau0603.414.0.html orig link] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070103145836/http://www.iau.org/iau0603.414.0.html |date=2007-01-03 }}) The practical meaning of "cleared the neighborhood" is that a planet is comparatively massive enough for its gravitation to control the orbits of all objects in its vicinity. By the IAU's definition, there are eight planets in the [[Solar System]]; four [[terrestrial planet]]s (Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars) and four [[giant planet]]s, which can be divided further into two [[gas giant]]s (Jupiter and Saturn) and two [[ice giant]]s (Uranus and Neptune). When excluding the Sun, the four giant planets account for more than 99 percent of the mass of the Solar System. {{clear right}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- ! colspan="2" style="background: #fffdd0;" |   ! style="background: #efe;" | *[[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]][http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/mercuryfact.html NASA Mercury Fact Sheet] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151106171436/http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/mercuryfact.html |date=2015-11-06 }} and [http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Mercury&Display=Facts NASA Solar System Exploration Factsheet] ''NASA'' Retrieved on 2008-11-17 (unless otherwise cited) ! style="background: #efe;" | *[[Venus]][http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/venusfact.html NASA Venus Factsheet] {{Webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/6ftO4K7lC?url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/venusfact.html |date=2016-03-10 }} and [http://sse.jpl.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Venus&Display=Facts&System=Metric NASA Solar System Exploration Factsheet] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060929003116/http://sse.jpl.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Venus&Display=Facts&System=Metric |date=2006-09-29 }} ''NASA'' Retrieved on 2008-11-17 (unless otherwise cited) ! [[asteroid]] | bgcolor="#eeffff" width=50 style="text-align: left" |‡
[[plutoid]] |} The IAU, the internationally recognized authority for assigning designations to celestial bodies, defines [[dwarf planet]]s as bodies that are large enough to have achieved [[hydrostatic equilibrium]], but have not cleared their neighbourhoods of similar objects. Since 2008, there have been five dwarf planets recognized by the IAU. [[Ceres (dwarf planet)|Ceres]] orbits in the [[asteroid belt]], between the orbits of [[Mars]] and [[Jupiter]]. The others orbit beyond Neptune and are subclassified as [[plutoid]]s. {| class="wikitable" border="1" style="text-align: center;" |- ! colspan="2" style="background: #fffdd0;" | ! style="background: #f0dc82;" | †{{dwarfplanet|Ceres}}{{cite web |title=NASA Asteroid Factsheet |url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/asteroidfact.html |accessdate=2008-11-17 |work=NASA |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/5msUtb6sU?url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/asteroidfact.html |archive-date=2010-01-18 |dead-url=yes }} ! style="background: #eff;" | ‡{{dwarfplanet|Pluto}}[http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/plutofact.html NASA Pluto factsheet] and [http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Pluto&Display=Facts NASA Solar System Exploration Pluto Factsheet] Retrieved on 2008-11-17 (unless otherwise cited) ! style="background: #eff;" | ‡{{dwarfplanet|Haumea}}(i) {{cite journal |first1=Alexandra C. |last1=Lockwood |first2=Michael (Mike) E. |last2=Brown |author-link2=Michael E. Dozens more could have been included.{{cite web |title=The Dwarf Planets |first=Michael (Mike) E. |last=Brown |publisher=Caltech |url=http://www.gps.caltech.edu/~mbrown/dwarfplanets/ |accessdate=2008-09-25 }} Both [[50000 Quaoar|Quaoar]] and [[90482 Orcus|Orcus]] have known moons that have allowed the mass of the systems to be determined. Both are more massive than the 5{{e|20}} kg recommendation of the [[IAU definition of planet#Draft proposal|IAU 2006 draft proposal]] as sufficient for classification as a dwarf planet.{{cite web |title=The Path to Defining Planets |first=Owen |last=Gingerich |author-link=Owen Gingerich |work=Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics and IAU EC Planet Definition Committee chair |date=2006-08-16 |url=https://www.iau.org/static/publications/ga_newspapers/20060812.pdf |accessdate=2007-03-13 |format=PDF |page=4 }} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- ! [[Satellite of Pluto]] |} {{see also|List of natural satellites of the Solar System}} There are 19 [[natural satellite]]s in the Solar System that are known to be massive enough to be close to hydrostatic equilibrium. [[Alan Stern]] calls these ''satellite planets'', although the term ''major moon'' is more common. Several of these were once in equilibrium but are no longer: these include all of the moons listed for Saturn apart from Titan and Rhea. Other moons that were once in equilibrium but are no longer very round, such as Saturn's [[Phoebe (moon)|Phoebe]], are not included. Satellites are listed first in order from the Sun, and second in order from their parent body. {| class="wikitable" border="1" style="text-align: center;" |- ! colspan="2" style="background: #fffdd0;" | ! Hilton.{{cite web |first=James L. |last=Hilton |title=When did asteroids become minor planets? |work=U.S. Naval Observatory |url=http://sd-www.jhuapl.edu/weaver_projects/GPD/Contributed_Talks/hilton_gpd_poster.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2008-10-25 }} The Moon is the only natural satellite with an astronomical symbol, and Pluto and Ceres the only dwarf planets. | item4_value = 18 | 4 = {{note label|R|r|none}}Uranus satellite info taken from NASA Uranian Satellite Fact Sheet.{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/uraniansatfact.html|title=NASA Uranian Satellite Fact Sheet|publisher=NASA|accessdate=2008-11-17|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/5msK7jx96?url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/uraniansatfact.html|archive-date=2010-01-18|dead-url=yes|df=}} | item5_value = 19 | 5 = {{note label|S|s|none}}Radii for plutoid candidates taken from material published by John A. Stansberry et al. | item6_value = 21 | 6 = {{note label|U|u|none}}Axial tilts for most satellites assumed to be zero in accordance with the Explanatory Supplement to the Astronomical Almanac: "In the absence of other information, the axis of rotation is assumed to be normal to the mean orbital plane."{{cite book |title=Explanatory Supplement to the Astronomical Almanac |editor-first=P. Kenneth |editor-last=Seidelmann |publisher=University Science Books |date=1992 |page=384 }} | item7_value = 22 | 7 = {{note label|V|v|none}}Natural satellite numbers taken from material published by Scott S. Sheppard.{{cite web |title=The Jupiter Satellite Page |first=Scott S. |last=Sheppard |work=Carnegie Institution for Science, Department of Terrestrial Magnetism |url=http://www.dtm.ciw.edu/users/sheppard/satellites |accessdate=2008-04-02 }} }} === Manual calculations (unless otherwise cited) === {{ordered list|type=a | item1_value = 1 | 1 = {{note label|A|a|none}} Surface area ''A'' derived from the radius using \begin{smallmatrix}A=4\pi r^2 \end{smallmatrix}, assuming sphericity. | item2_value = 2 | 2 = {{note label|B|b|none}} Volume ''V'' derived from the radius using \begin{smallmatrix}V=\frac{4}{3}\pi r^3 \end{smallmatrix}, assuming sphericity. | item3_value = 3 | 3 = {{note label|C|c|none}} Density derived from the mass divided by the volume. | item4_value = 4 | 4 = {{note label|D|d|none}} Surface gravity derived from the mass ''m'', the [[gravitational constant]] ''G'' and the radius ''r'': ''G*m/r2 ''. | item5_value = 5 | 5 = {{note label|E|e|none}} Escape velocity derived from the mass ''m'', the [[gravitational constant]] ''G'' and the radius ''r'': ''sqrt((2*G*m)/r) ''. | item6_value = 14 | 6 = {{note label|N|n|none}} Orbital speed is calculated using the mean orbital radius and the orbital period, assuming a circular orbit. | item7_value = 20 | 7 = {{note label|T|t|none}} Assuming a density of 2.0 | item8_value = 23 | 8 = {{note label|W|w|none}} Calculated using the formula \begin{smallmatrix}T\ =\ \frac{T_{\textrm{eff}}(1-qp_{\nu})^{1/4}}{\sqrt{2}}\sqrt{52/r},\end{smallmatrix} where Teff =54.8 K at 52 AU, p_{\nu} is the geometric albedo, ''q''=0.8 is the [[Bond albedo#Phase integral|phase integral]], and r is the distance from the Sun in AU. This formula is a simplified version of that in section 2.2 of Stansberry et al., 2007, where emissivity and beaming parameter were assumed equal unity, and \pi was replaced with 4 accounting for the difference between circle and sphere. All parameters mentioned above were taken from the same paper. | item9_value = 27 | 9 = {{note label|AA|aa|none}}Calculated using the formula \begin{smallmatrix}D=\frac{1329}{\sqrt{p}}10^{-0.2H}\end{smallmatrix}, where H is the absolute magnitude, p is the geometric albedo and D is the diameter in km, and assuming an albedo of 0.15, as per Dan Bruton.{{cite web |title=Conversion of Absolute Magnitude to Diameter for Minor Planets |publisher=Department of Physics & Astronomy (Stephen F. Austin State University) |first=Dan |last=Bruton |url=http://www.physics.sfasu.edu/astro/asteroids/sizemagnitude.html |accessdate=2009-01-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323180835/http://www.physics.sfasu.edu/astro/asteroids/sizemagnitude.html |archivedate=2010-03-23 }} | item10_value = 30 | 10 = {{note label|AD|ad|none}} Mass derived from the density multipied by the volume. }} === Individual calculations === {{ordered list|type=a | item1_value = 25 | 1 = {{note label|Y|y|none}}Derived from density | item2_value = 26 | 2 = {{note label|Z|z|none}} Surface area was calculated using the formula for a scalene [[ellipsoid]]: :\begin{smallmatrix}2\pi\left(c^2+b\sqrt{a^2-c^2}E(\alpha,m)+\frac{bc^2}{\sqrt{a^2-c^2}}F(\alpha,m)\right),\,\!\end{smallmatrix} where \begin{smallmatrix}\alpha=\arccos\left(\frac{c}{a}\right)\,\,\!\end{smallmatrix} is the modular angle, or '''[[angular eccentricity]]'''; \begin{smallmatrix}m=\frac{b^2-c^2}{b^2\sin(\alpha)^2}\,\!\end{smallmatrix} and \begin{smallmatrix}F(\alpha,m)\,\!\end{smallmatrix}, \begin{smallmatrix}E(\alpha,m)\,\!\end{smallmatrix} are the incomplete [[elliptic integral]]s of the first and second kind, respectively. The values 980 km, 759 km, and 498 km were used for a, b, and c respectively. }} === Other notes === {{ordered list|type=a | item1_value = 6 | 1 = {{note label|F|f|none}} Relative to Earth | item2_value = 7 | 2 = {{note label|G|g|none}} [[Orbital period|Sidereal]] | item3_value = 8 | 3 = {{note label|H|h|none}} [[Retrograde motion|Retrograde]] | item4_value = 9 | 4 = {{note label|I|i|none}} The inclination of the body's [[equator]] from its [[orbit]]. | item5_value = 10 | 5 = {{note label|J|j|none}} At pressure of 1 bar | item6_value = 11 | 6 = {{note label|K|k|none}} At sea level | item7_value = 12 | 7 = {{note label|L|l|none}} The ratio between the mass of the object and those in its immediate neighborhood. Used to distinguish between a planet and a dwarf planet. | item8_value = 13 | 8 = {{note label|M|m|none}} This object's rotation is synchronous with its orbital period, meaning that it only ever shows one face to its primary. | item9_value = 24 | 9 = {{note label|X|x|none}} Objects' planetary discriminants based on their similar orbits to Eris. Sedna's population is currently too little-known for a planetary discriminant to be determined. | item10_value = 28 | 10 = {{note label|AB|ab|none}}Proteus average diameter: 210 km; Mimas average diameter: 199 km | item11_value = 29 | 11 = {{note label|AC|ac|none}} "Unless otherwise cited" means that the information contained in the citation is applicable to an entire line or column of a chart, unless another citation specifically notes otherwise. }} {{ref end}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} == See also == * [[List of former planets]] {{Solar System}} {{Featured list}} [[Category:Lists of Solar System objects|Hydrostatic equilibrium]] [[Category:Planemos|*]]

page.title: List of national parks of Thailand

revision.comment: added [[Category:Lists of tourist attractions in Thailand]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
[[Image:Haeo Suwat waterfall.JPG|right|thumb|300px|Haeo Suwat waterfall in [[Khao Yai National Park]], Thailand's first national park, designated in 1961.]]
[[National park]]s in [[Thailand]] ({{lang-th|อุทยานแห่งชาติ}}) are defined as ''an area that contains natural resources of ecological importance or unique beauty, or flora and fauna of special importance''. {{Asof|2015}} Thailand's protected areas included 147 national parks, 58 wildlife sanctuaries, 67 non-hunting areas, and 120 forest parks. They cover almost 20 percent of the kingdom’s territory.<ref name="DNP-UNDP-2015">{{cite book|last1=Suksawang|first1=Songtam|last2=McNeely|first2=Jeffrey A|title=Parks for Life: Why We Love Thailand's National Parks|date=2015|publisher=Department of National Parks, Wildlife, and Plant Conservation (DNP); United Nations Development Programme (UNDP)|location=Bangkok|isbn=978-616-316-256-4|url=http://www.th.undp.org/content/dam/thailand/docs/publications/UNDP_TH_Parks_for_Life.pdf|accessdate=29 January 2017}}</ref>{{RP|10}}
The parks are administered by the National Park, Wildlife and Plant Conservation Department (DNP), of the [[Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (Thailand)|Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment]] (MNRE). The department was created in 2002, and took over the national parks from the [[Royal Forest Department]] of the Ministry of Agriculture.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://portal.dnp.go.th/Content?contentId=5|title=ประวัติความเป็นมา|language=Thai|accessdate=2017-01-29|work=Department of National Parks, Wildlife and Plant Conservation}}</ref>
The first national park was [[Khao Yai National Park|Khao Yai]] in 1961, when the ''National Park Act B.E. 2504'' was passed. The first marine park was [[Khao Sam Roi Yot National Park|Khao Sam Roi Yot]], established in 1966. In 1993 the administration of the national parks was split into two divisions, one for the terrestrial and one for the Marine National Park Division (MNPD).<ref name="MeprasertUniversity2006">{{cite book|last1=Meprasert|first1=Somrudee|author2=Oregon State University|title=The 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami: Tourism impacts and recovery progress in Thailand's marine national parks|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BwJB6ufVUCgC&pg=PA11|accessdate=October 2, 2011|year=2006|publisher=ProQuest|isbn=978-0-542-96361-2|pages=11–}}</ref>
Controversies about Thailand's national parks include complaints over excessive development and allotment of private concessions. [[Ko Samet]], and other island-based national parks, are particularly impacted by the activities of private concessions, often in the form of excessive bungalow developments. Many of the northern parks are greatly impacted by illegal [[swidden farming]] and poaching.
There are 33 national parks and three marine parks in the process of creation, and are scheduled to be officially announced in the [[Royal Thai Government Gazette]] in the future.{{cn|date=December 2017}}
==National parks of Thailand== [[Image:Thailand 467 phu hin ronkl np.jpg|right|thumb|A view over [[Phu Hin Rong Kla National Park]], Loei, Phitsanulok and Phetchabun Provinces.]] [[Image:KaengSophaBelow.jpg|right|thumb|[[Namtok Kaeng Sopha|Kaeng Sopha Waterfall]], [[Thung Salaeng Luang National Park]].]] [[Image:Phra Phuttha Chai National Park - around visitor center.jpg|thumb|right|[[Phra Puttachai National Park]], [[Saraburi Province]]]] [[File:Place WFVajiradhara.jpg|thumb|Wachirathan (lit. "Diamond Creek") waterfall on [[Doi Inthanon]], the [[List of countries by highest point|highest mountain]] in Thailand.]] [[Image:Phetchabun mountains.jpg|thumb|right|[[Pa Hin Ngam National Park]]]] [[Image:Great hornbill flying.jpg|thumb|right|[[Great hornbill]], [[Khao Yai National Park]]]] [[Image:KHAOYAI.JPG|right|thumb|[[Khao Yai National Park]], the second largest in Thailand, covering an area of 2,168 square kilometers.]] [[Image:Erawan Waterfall, Kanchanaburi Province, Thailand - June 2004.jpg|right|thumb|The waterfall at [[Erawan National Park]], [[Kanchanaburi Province]].]] [[File:ลังกาน้อย ลังกาหลวง อช ขุนแจ 2.jpg|right|thumb|[[Khun Chae National Park]], [[Chiang Rai Province]].]] [[Image:Chieo-Lan-See01.JPG|thumb|right|[[Khao Sok National Park]]]] [[Image:Ang Thong 1.jpg|right|thumb|[[Ang Thong National Park]]]] [[Image:P1121466.JPG|right|thumb|Sunset at [[Surin Islands|Mu Ko Surin National Marine Park]], [[Phang Nga Province]].]] [[Image:Phraya Nakhon Cave.jpg|right|thumb|Phraya Nakhon Cave in [[Khao Sam Roi Yot National Park]], Thailand's first national marine park.]] [[Image:Hat Laem Sala.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Khao Sam Roi Yot National Park]]]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=October 2015}} {{International relations theory sidebar|Marxism}} '''Marxist and neo-Marxist international relations theories''' are paradigms which reject the [[realism in international relations|realist]]/[[Liberal international relations theory|liberal]] view of state conflict or cooperation, instead focusing on the economic and material aspects. It purports to reveal how the economy trumps other concerns, which allows for the elevation of class as the focus of the study.
== Leninism == {{main|Leninism}} In the 19th century, [[Karl Marx]] and [[Friedrich Engels]] wrote that the main source of instability in the international system would be [[Capitalism|capitalist]] [[globalization]], more specifically the conflict between two classes: the [[Nationalism|national]] [[bourgeoisie]] and the [[Cosmopolitanism|cosmopolitan]] [[proletariat]]. [[Historical materialism]] was going to be [[Marxism]]’s guideline in understanding the processes both in domestic and international affairs. Thus, for Marx human history has been a struggle to satisfy material needs and to resists class domination and exploitation. Despite ideological criticism, Marxism has strong empirical advantages on its side. Firstly, by emphasizing injustice and inequality it is very relevant to every period of time as these two failures of the human society have never been absent. Marxism is a structural theory just like [[Neorealism (international relations)|neorealism]], but it focuses on the economic sector instead of the military-political one. Its analysis reflects the relation between [[Base and superstructure|the base (the modes of production) and the superstructure (political institutions)]]. The source of structural effects is not [[Anarchy (international relations)|anarchy]], but the [[Capitalist mode of production (Marxist theory)|capitalist mode of production]] which defines unjust political institutions and state relations.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sonda|first1=Claudiu|title=Guide to International Relations II: Marxism and Constructivism|url=http://www.theworldreporter.com/2014/05/guide-international-relations-ii-marxism-constructivism.html|website=World Reporter|accessdate=23 October 2015}}</ref>
This economic reductionism is considered also to be a central flaw. As a solution, the [[Neo-Gramscianism|neo-Gramscian]] school proposed a further development. By combining global capitalism, state structure and political-economic institutions, they managed to create a theory of [[global hegemony]] (ideological domination). According to this theory, hegemony is maintained through close cooperation between powerful elites inside and outside the core regions of the world system. Global governance is constituted by political and economic institutions that put pressure on the less developed and unstable peripheral countries.
From an [[Epistemology|epistemological]] point of view, Marxism created the foundations for [[critical theory]] and it is superior in this sense to the dominant approaches of Anglo-American international relations that are problem-solving theories. As any other critical theory, Marxism has a normative interest in identifying possibilities for social transformation and how theory is instrumental to power. This is why Marx wrote about capitalism with an interest in the social forces that would bring about its downfall hoping that humanity would be free from domination and exploitation. Realists in particular see this to be politically motivated and not objective and neutral. The normative disadvantage of Marxism is that it can be seen as Eurocentric by promoting [[Age of Enlightenment|the Enlightenment]] ideal of cosmopolitanism.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Paul|first1=Kegan|title=Journal of Politics|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=6130672|website=Cambridge Library|accessdate=23 October 2015}}</ref>
== Dependency theory == {{main|Dependency theory}} Linked in with Marxist theories is [[dependency theory]] which argues that [[Developed country|developed countries]] in their pursuit of power penetrate developing states through political advisors, missionaries, experts and multi-national corporations (MNCs) to integrate them into the capitalist system in order to appropriate natural resources and foster dependence by [[Developing country|developing countries]] on developed countries.
== World-systems theory == {{main|World-systems theory|Immanuel Wallerstein}}
== Criticisms == Realists and liberals criticize Marxist conflict theories for ideological and consequentialist reasons. [[Postpositivism|Postpositivists]] disagree with Marxists' elevation of [[class conflict]] as the most significant aspect of human life and the key to understanding all human history and behavior.
== See also == * [[Critical international relations theory]] * [[International relations theory]] * [[Marxism]]
== References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Marxist International Relations Theory}} [[Category:International relations theory]] [[Category:Marxism]]
